prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Relationship to other forms of transfer and consolidation—Comparison to consolidation

para.paratext: The statute authorizes transfer for “coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.” Transfer can thus facilitate consolidation; it can also permit something different, coordination. The rules of procedure permitting consolidation do not have this flexibility.[1]

The Panel does not, however, either consolidate or coordinate cases. The Panel may transfer cases to a single court, but that transferee court must determine what, if any, consolidation or coordination is appropriate.[2] Indeed, the Panel has repeatedly stated that it assumes the transferee court will exercise its broad discretion in managing the transferred case.[3]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

The power of the transferee court to determine these matters is discussed in Chapter 9. See also In re Bear Creek Technologies, Inc., ('722) Patent Litigation, 858 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2012) (noting that Panel doesn't consolidate actions; it only transfers and then leaves to transferee judge to decide how to manage cases).

See, e.g., In re America Online Spin-Off Accounts Litigation, 310 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (court leaves to transferee to distinguish between “coordination” and “consolidation”); In re “Factor VIII or IX Concentrate Blood Products” Products Liability Litigation, 303 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (transferee can determine how to manage cases with differening needs); In re Medical Waste Services Antitrust Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2003) (transferee court can order “separate tracks” to deal with cases in different procedural postures); In re Xcel Energy, Inc., 254 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2003) (transferee court to determine extent of coordination); In re Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., Research Reports Securities Litigation, 223 F. Supp. 2d 1388 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (Panel defers to transferee court to determine if separation of one case is appropriate and to suggest remand, if appropriate); In re Tri-State Crematory Lit., 206 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (concerns about individual needs of transferred cases can be decided by transferee court); In re Phenylpropanolamine (PPA) Products Liability Litigation, 173 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2001) (Panel discusses how transferee court can manage common and non-common issues together).
